subject: Economics
title: The Certainty Effect: Why We Hate Probabilities
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: The Certainty Effect: Why We Hate Probabilities.

hook.text: Most people prefer a guaranteed $800 over a 90% chance of $1,000.

buildup.text: The certainty effect: people overweight certain outcomes and underweight merely probable ones.

discovery.text: This is why people buy overpriced insurance for cheap electronics.

twist.text: But flip it: a certain loss of $800 or 90% chance of losing $1,000? Now people gamble. Certainty repels us with losses.

climax.text: We crave certainty for gains and avoid certainty for losses. The asymmetry makes us predictably irrational.

punchline.text: A sure thing feels infinitely better than almost sure.

quiz.question: What is the certainty effect?
options: People prefer guaranteed outcomes for gains even when gambles have higher expected value
People always choose the risky option
People are equally rational with all probabilities
